casebody.data:
UNITED STATES of America, Plaintiff-Appellee v. Michael BELL, Defendant-Appellant. No. 08-31192

Conference Calendar.

United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit. Oct. 20, 2009. Cristina Walker, Assistant U.S. Attorney, U.S. Attorney’s Office, Western District of Louisiana, Shreveport, LA, for Plaintiff-Appellee. Betty Lee Marak, Federal Public Defender’s Office, Western District of Louisiana, Shreveport, LA, for Defendant-Appellant. Before WIENER, BENAVIDES, and STEWART, Circuit Judges. PER CURIAM: *

*715Michael Bell appeals the sentence imposed following the district court’s reduction of his sentence pursuant to 18 U.S.C. § 3582(c)(2). Bell argues that the holding in United States v. Booker, 543 U.S. 220, 125 S.Ct. 738, 160 L.Ed.2d 621 (2005), applies in § 3582(c)(2) proceedings and that the district court abused its discretion by not imposing a sentence below the amended guidelines sentencing range. Bell’s arguments are foreclosed by United States v. Doublin, 572 F.3d 235, 236-39 (5th Cir.2009), petition for cert. filed (Sept. 21, 2009) (No. 09-6657).

AFFIRMED.

Pursuant to 5th Cir. R. 47.5, the court has determined that this opinion should not be *715published and is not precedent except under the limited circumstances set forth in 5th Cir R. 47.5.4.
